content: Sorry I missed the meeting today. I think we should probably find another time.
But I guess @Albin Stjerna and I did a bit of a sync the other day anyhow
@Keith Yeung -- saw your message. One thing that I think would be helpful is to continue some of the work that @Albin Stjerna was doing on trying to find good benchmarks.
I think as we proceed we'll find other good things to split off

Sorry I missed the meeting today. I think we should probably find another time.

(this time is often a bit chaotic for me)
i presume that by good benchmarks, you mean looking for rust programs that stretches the perf of polonius?
yeah so @Albin Stjerna did some work in this topic doing a bunch of measurements and categorizing them
I think what we want to do is to kind of find some 'good exampes' that fit different definitions
i was going to write up some thoughts on how to do this, e.g. one thought I had is to try and make a spreadsheet with like "how many facts of each kind are there"
I suspect that some benhcmarks have large number of cfg points, other large numbers of subtype relatons, whatever
so, i recall that a couple of the fetch algorithms implemented in servo deals with complicated cases of borrowing
specifically the assignment to internal_response, based on some other conditions

Sorry I missed the meeting today. I think we should probably find another time.

yes, with DST it's a bit late for me :(
@Keith Yeung Also, if you want the things I have made (modifications to rustc-perf, a Jupyter notebook to analyse the results, and my scripts for scraping and compiling crates), just shout!
